In 1973 an entire race team drove in cars of matching design - it was the first coherent team style that the sport had seen. The three coloured stripes of blue, violet and red - set against a brilliant white background - would come to characterise the image of BMW Motorsport and continue to define the look to this day. The unbeatable BMW 3.0 CSL Coupés, kitted out in these colours, soon became known to everybody in the world of motor racing, bringing home the Touring Car Grand Prix at the Nürburgring at the very first attempt. #TriviaTuesday BMW Classic. Water injection made its debut under the bonnet of the BMW M4 MotoGP Safety Car. The BMW Group Innovation Days marked the first presentation of direct water injection in the prototype of a model from the BMW core brand. The precisely controlled injection of water into the engine cylinders produces a cooling effect that boosts power and torque, particularly when operating at - or close to - full throttle, and at the same time it reduces fuel consumption and emissions. With BMW Gesture Control in the all-new BMW 7 Series, selected functions can be operated by means of defined hand movements. Simple gestures such as 'swiping' or 'pointing' are identified in the recognition area above the centre console and trigger a variety of functions such as accepting or rejecting an incoming telephone call. Volume can be adjusted by circular motions of the index finger. BMW Gesture Control complements the existing control systems such as the iDrive Touch Controller. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

The Executive Lounge rear console houses the Touch Command system. This removable 7-inch tablet computer allows the user to control the infotainment and comfort functions available in the rear of the all-new BMW 7 Series. It can also be used to play back external audio and video files, as a games console, or to surf the internet. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

The all-new BMW 7 Series is the world’s first series-produced car that owners will be able to manoeuvre in or out of forward-parking spaces or garages without anyone at the wheel. The Remote Control Parking function allows the driver to conveniently hop out of the vehicle before parking it. The driver activates the remote-controlled parking function from outside the vehicle via the BMW display key. The entire parking procedure is monitored by Park Distance Control (PDC), the Parking assistant and the Surround View sensors. In order to use the remote-controlled parking function, the vehicle has to be straight and centered, facing the parking space or garage. During the parking procedure the driver can bring the vehicle to a controlled stop if necessary. Once parked, the engine can be switched off via the key. And when it's time to move on, the engine can also be restarted via the key. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

Slide up to unlock the future of #drivingluxury.
The BMW display key of the all-new BMW 7 Series shows a range of information about the vehicle's status and allows selected functions to be controlled via the integrated touch display. The time can be displayed, along with remaining fuel and current range, service notifications, as well as the current status of the central locking system, the windows and the glass roof. The BMW display key can also be used to operate Auxiliary heating and Remote Control Parking. Timeline Photos
